page.title: 05LOCAL HISTORY-BUTETOWN
page.content: Industrial development of the 19th Century paid little heed to any form of planning and houses were generally built in a haphazard fashion.However, Butetown is an exception to the rule.Built between 1802 and 1804 it was originally intended as a{model {village}to accommodate the workers of the nearby Union Ironworks.Its Welsh name,{Trefnewyd},Newtown,gives an indication of the overall scheme. The houses themselves are of an impressive terraced layout with both two and three storey blocks built on both sides of a very wide road,which points in the direction of the ironworks.In the last decade, the houses have been completely modernised internally and still appear to be an impressive example of industrial 19th Century architecture.
